newsitem.title: HONG KONG: New World Infra seeking rating review.
newsitem.headline: New World Infra seeking rating review.

text.p: HONG KONG, May 23 (Reuter) New World Infrastructure Ltd is asking for a credit rating review, managing director Douglas Chan said at a loan signing ceremony on Friday.

New World Infrastructure has a "split rating", Chan said. It is rated BBB-minus by Standard and Poor's Corp, the lowest investment grade rating, while Moody's Investors Service has assigned the company a Ba1, a notch below investment grade.
Chan said he hoped the company could receive an investment grade rating from both rating agencies.

Since May this year, New World Infrastructure has raised an estimated HK$7 billion, with around HK$2 billion through a share placement earlier this month and US$650 million (HK$5.02 billion) via a loan syndication, chairman Henry Cheng said.
Cheng said the company would spend the HK$2 billion mainly on water treatment projects in China, whereas the proceeds from the loan facility would be used for general working capital.
Chan added the rate of return from the company's water treatment projects is around 18 percent while its road projects yield 20 percent and its power investments around 18 percent.
At present, the company has a gearing ratio of around 22 percent. Its gearing will rise to 90 percent if the US$650 million loan facility is fully drawn, Cheng said.

Cheng added that the company still has the capacity to borrow a further HK$5-6 billion, thereby pushing its gearing to a maximum of 150 percent. But he stressed that the company has no urgent funding requirements.
As for the company's expansion plan, Douglas Chan said the New World Infrastructure has invested close to US$1 billion in new projects in China for the past 18 months.
Chan said "I would like to be as active as the last 18 months," when asked if the company would be more active in the coming 18 months.
